text:
What time do children start talking and how to help them
06 Nov 2019, 19:15 by Ekaterina Komissarova
If the baby is already 15 months old and the first word has not been sounded, this is an alarming signal.
When the kids start talking
There is no single answer to this question. The thing is that children's speech occurs * much earlier than the conscious "mother" or "give" sounds. * Source: Baby milestone: Talking
The first form of communication is crying. Parents know that it differs depending on what the child wants to convey. For example, a piercing cry most likely means that the baby needs food, and a groaning whimper - that it's time to change the diaper.
Sounds similar to real words appear at the age of 4‚Äì6 months. By this time, the speech apparatus is being improved and the child begins to experiment, opening and closing his mouth, inhaling and exhaling, moving his tongue, changing the shape of the lips. So * infant babble appears: ‚Äúa-ba-ba‚Äù, ‚Äúaha‚Äù or even ‚Äúmother.‚Äù * Source: When Do Babies Start Talking?
But you should not take such first words seriously: this is an accident. The child does not yet associate his ‚Äúmother‚Äù, ‚Äúwoman‚Äù or ‚Äúgive‚Äù with specific people or actions.
If a person assures that his child spoke at 7‚Äì9 months, he is either mistaken or wishful thinking.
The first meaningful word appears * between the ages of 11 and 12 months. And then the process goes like an avalanche. By the year the child usually knows and pronounces not one, but from 2 to 20 words: ‚Äúmother‚Äù, ‚Äúfather‚Äù, ‚Äúwoman‚Äù, ‚Äúgive‚Äù and sometimes distorted, but nevertheless understandable ‚Äútu-tu‚Äù (train) , ‚ÄúBang‚Äù (fall) or ‚Äúam‚Äù (is). * Source: Ontogenesis of speech development
Actually, the year can be considered the very boundary after which confident speech arises. Of course, the children are different: someone starts chatting at 11 months, and someone keeps quiet for up to a year with a tail (babble does not count). But there is an important time point. If the child does not pronounce * a single conscious word by 15 months, it is imperative to consult a pediatrician. He may need to undergo additional tests, such as checking his hearing or visiting a neurologist. * Source: Your Child Talking Timeline
How to understand that a child has speech problems
Mom is the most important expert on her own baby. Therefore, if it seems to her that the child has difficulty pronouncing sounds or responding to what she heard, this is already enough to talk with the doctor.
But besides ‚Äúit seems‚Äù there are objective signs of speech problems. They vary by age.

3-4 months: the child does not babble, does not experiment with sounds.
5-6 months: does not respond to unexpected sounds, does not turn his head to a call, does not laugh.
8‚Äì9 months: does not respond to its own name, babble is rare and monotonous.
12 months: does not pronounce a single word, not even ‚Äúmother‚Äù, ‚Äúgive‚Äù or ‚Äúon‚Äù.
13-18 months: does not show simple objects in the picture or around (for example, does not understand the question "Where is the ball?"), Does not have at least six words in the vocabulary by the age of 18 months and does not learn new ones.

Another alarming symptom is the loss of acquired language skills. For example, if by the age of 18 months a child uses ‚Äúnormative‚Äù six words, but you know for sure that there were more than 20 of them only a couple of months ago, tell the pediatrician about such a regression.
How to help your child speak
The best way is to create all the conditions for communication. Here are the three most important things every parent should do.
1. Talk
No need to chat without a break. Just talk to your child when you spend time together.

Name the things you hold in your hands or hold out to the baby: ‚ÄúThis is a ball. And this is a machine. ‚Äù
Describe what you are doing: ‚ÄúNow we put on our pants. And now - a jacket. And let's go for a walk! ‚Äù
Explain what is happening around: ‚ÄúOooh, what a loud car went!‚Äù, ‚ÄúKar! This crow is croaking, ‚Äù‚Äú But my mother‚Äôs phone rings. ‚Äù
Ask questions: ‚ÄúDo you hear how dad calls us? We ran to him! ‚Äù,‚Äú Your bunny is probably tired? ‚Äù Does he want to go to bed? ‚Äù
Sing lullabies.

2. Read aloud
Reading shows the child that there are many different words, teaches you to make sentences, demonstrates how the action develops. This prompts him to tell his own stories, for example, about how dolls play with each other, why the machine is hidden or why he does not want to eat your soup.
3. Listen
Be grateful for the stories: show interest, listen carefully, look in the eye. Make the child want to talk to you about what is happening around you. This will become an incentive for him to use more words and put them into more complex sentences.
